We provide a purely categorical definition of quantum theory. The definition is based on a small number of axioms that are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. The axioms are similar to those of classical mechanics and classical field theory. The definition is intended to be a foundation for a reconstruction program for quantum theory. The program is based on the idea that the axioms of quantum theory are the minimal set of axioms that are consistent with the laws of physics.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in a wide range of animals, including humans. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, and a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we present a genomic and transcriptomic analysis of two myxozoan species and a cnidarian parasite, and we show that the Myxozoa are a sister group to the cnidarians. We also show that the myxozoan body plan was greatly reduced in terms of both genome size and gene content. Our results provide insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. This work will be of interest to a broad range of researchers interested in the evolution of parasites and parasites of parasites.

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is a common strategy used by pathogens to survive and propagate in their host. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block STAT1 and STAT2 nuclear translocation in order to impair transcriptional induction of IFN-stimulated genes. Our results demonstrate that the viral accessory protein Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its IFN antagonistic function. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the host immune response and may help in the development of new strategies to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1, but the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by the middle of the 21st century, and the demand for food is expected to increase by 50% to meet this demand. This study shows that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase substantially. This study also shows that the instability in global grain trade and international grain prices will be exacerbated by climate change. These results highlight the need for investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, despite decades of research, we still do not know how diverse LMH assemblages partition food resources. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant LMH species in semiarid African savanna. Our results show that LMH partition food resources in a variety of ways, including differential consumption of grasses versus nongrasses and spatiotemporal stratification in use of different parts of the same plant. Nonetheless, LMH diversity was not linked to the diversity of the food resources available, suggesting that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results highlight the need to consider the species-level diversity of LMH when studying their interactions with plants and biodiversity. This is important for understanding the drivers of biodiversity in African savanna and beyond.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Moreover, the majority of businesses expect to apply for government loans, but many anticipate problems accessing the program. Our results suggest that the government should consider alternative funding mechanisms to increase the likelihood that small businesses will be able to access the funds they need.

Plastic debris in the ocean is a major concern for the marine environment. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the plastic debris in the open ocean is mostly concentrated in the convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres, but in much smaller amounts than expected. This is due to the selective removal of the plastic debris by the food webs and the ocean interior. Our results point at the importance of the size distribution of the plastic debris in the ocean, and the need for further studies on the fate of the missing plastic debris.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. In this study, we show that the ability to provide for offspring, either through the provision of food or care, is a strong driver of reproductive output. We also show that the effect of provisioning is not limited to the provision of food, but also applies to the provision of care from other individuals. This study provides a framework for understanding the evolution of provisioning in mammals and the evolution of domestication. It also provides a framework for understanding the evolution of allonursing in humans.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the central nervous system. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is currently in phase II clinical trials for the treatment of epilepsy, is able to reduce the load of α-syn in oligodendrocytes and to limit the neurotoxic effects of α-syn aggregation in a mouse model of MSA. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate for the treatment of MSA. This is the first report of the effects of VX-765 in a mouse model of MSA. Our results provide an in vivo proof of concept for the potential of this drug to slow down the progression of MSA. This study opens the door to the development of VX-765 as a therapeutic agent for MSA and other synucleinopathies. (PsycINFO Database Record

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It controls the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues, controls the contractility of the blood vessels, and controls hemostasis. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are highly specialized to perform these functions. The endothelium is also the site of communication between cells. This communication is important for the endothelium to control its functions. Here, the nature of the communication network has been addressed using single-cell Ca2+ imaging across thousands of endothelial cells in intact blood vessels. The findings reveal that the endothelial network design is effective for local and global efficiency in the interaction of the cells and rapid and robust communication between endothelial cells in order to efficiently control cardiovascular activity. This work provides a better understanding of the endothelium and its role in health and disease. It also provides a foundation for the development of new therapies for cardiovascular disease.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated unprecedented data challenges. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of data on the pandemic, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the pore of K+ channels, and it is the site of ion conduction. The selectivity filter is also the site of the activation gate, which is the gatekeeper of the channel. We have identified a key residue for the functional and structural coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. We have also demonstrated that the selectivity filter can be used as a structural switch to achieve closed-state inactivation. This work provides a structural basis for the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. It also provides a structural mechanism for the collapse of the selectivity filter, which is a key step in the opening of the channel.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to be important for the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is still being elucidated, and the potential for natural products to regulate the composition of the gut microbiome is an emerging area of research. Here, we report the discovery of a diverse array of natural products from anaerobic fungi that are thought to be part of the gut microbiome. These results support the hypothesis that anaerobic fungi synthesize a variety of natural products, which could be used as a source of novel therapeutics.

Social dominance is a key aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchy remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with a low probability to become dominant, directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identifies an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of personality traits in social behavior and may have implications for the treatment of anxiety disorders. (PsycINFO Database Record

The hemoglobin system is a key regulator of the timing of development and differentiation in the human body. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key regulator of the hemoglobin system in humans. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 is expressed in the fetal liver and is down-regulated in the adult bone marrow. We show that IGF2BP1 is a key regulator of the hemoglobin system in humans, and that it mediates the developmental silencing of the beta-globin gene. This study provides a mechanism for chronoregulation of the hemoglobin system in humans.

Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of effective therapies is a major challenge. In this study, we identified a mechanism of cancer cell resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis that is regulated by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. We found that the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis is frequently mutated in cancer, and that this mutation protects cancer cells from ferroptosis. We also found that this resistance is mediated by a lipogenesis pathway driven by sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1/stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1, a central regulator of lipid metabolism. Finally, we demonstrated that this mechanism of resistance can be overcome by targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway in combination with ferroptosis induction. These findings have implications for the development of new cancer therapies. (Show more)

The most common drugs used to treat hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). Our study shows that LCCBs activate a Ca2+ signaling pathway that promotes vascular remodeling. Our findings indicate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stromal-interacting molecule (STIM) Ca2+ sensor. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of bird populations associated with early-seral forests, but the decline of older-forest–associated species accelerated. Our findings highlight the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and the need to ensure that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge, and computational approaches are essential tools to this end. Here, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. The best candidate was tested in vitro and in vivo, and showed activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This approach can be used to design new antibiotics for other targets and for other pathogens. This work is expected to contribute to the development of new antibiotics. (Show more)

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, which makes it difficult to train the network and to apply it to problems with a large number of training samples. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and that consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. This makes it easier to train the network and to apply it to problems with a large number of training samples.

The Lake Malawi region is one of the most diverse freshwater ecosystems on Earth, and the lake has been a critical habitat for the evolution of the endemic cichlid fish species flock. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind, 1.3-My record of hydroclimate variability from Lake Malawi. The record shows a dramatic shift in the effective moisture regime at the MPT, which is consistent with far-field climate forcing. The lake level variations are dominated by extreme drought events during the Holocene, which are linked to the orbital forcing of the Earth’s orbit. The record provides a unique insight into the influence of hydroclimate variability on the evolution of the cichlid fish species flock.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This practice is associated with reduced sleep duration and quality, and with adverse consequences on general health. The mechanisms underlying the negative impact of electronic devices on sleep are not well understood. Here we show that the use of an electronic device in the hours before bedtime phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas (YDB) boundary is a key event in the Earth’s history, but the cause of the YDB is still debated. One of the proposed causes is the impact of a bolide. We show that the osmium isotopic composition of the sediments and magnetic grains/microspherules from the YDB sites in Arizona, Michigan, New Mexico, New Jersey, and Ohio is consistent with a terrestrial origin of the osmium. In contrast, the YDB site in Pennsylvania is remarkable in yielding 2- to 5-mm diameter spherules that are likely ejecta from an impact 12.9 ka ago. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the spherules indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its specific function in the development of autoimmunity and in different systemic diseases remains to be determined. Here, we report that the deletion of CTLA-4 in adult mice results in a spectrum of autoimmunity, which is not observed in congenital deficiency. This suggests that the role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is not limited to its function in the development of autoimmunity.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the origin and diversification of beetles remain poorly understood. We used a combination of genomic and fossil data to trace the evolution of beetles, revealing that the origin of beetles coincides with the origin of the plant kingdom, and that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates, the codiversification of beetles and plants, and the convergent acquisition of genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may also have broader implications for the development of other protein-based therapeutics.

We report the results of a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution. We find that, contrary to some predictions, larger populations do not enhance the performance of a technology (paper planes) in a transmission-chain experiment. We also find that the size of the population is inversely related to the performance of the technology, and that this relationship is not due to the size of the population enhancing cumulative cultural evolution. Our results suggest that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance cumulative cultural evolution. These results have implications for the evolution of technology and culture in general.

The strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. APOE E4 allele is associated with ∼12-fold increased risk for AD, whereas APOE E2 allele is associated with ∼twofold decreased risk. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also found that the presence of APOE E4 allele increases the accumulation of a protein involved in complement-mediated synapse degeneration in the brain. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, and they also suggest the hypothesis that APOE E4 may accelerate the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses in the brain, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis may help explain the increased risk of AD in APOE4 carriers

The Earth's inner core is a solid ball of iron that is 1,200 km in diameter and 1,700 km in height. It is the densest part of the Earth, and it is the only part of the Earth that is not in dynamic equilibrium with the rest of the planet. The inner core is a paradox because it is formed at a temperature that is too high for the stable, hexagonal, close-packed phase of iron to be formed, and it is not old enough for the stable, body-centered, cubic phase to have formed. We show that the stable, body-centered, cubic phase has a much higher nucleation rate than does the stable, hexagonal, close-packed phase, and thus the body-centered phase is the first step of the inner core formation. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are well known, the effects of acute marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that the brain responses to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA), are attenuated in marijuana abusers, who also have higher levels of negative emotionality and addiction severity. These findings suggest that the attenuated brain responses to methylphenidate in marijuana abusers might contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors. The findings also highlight the need to investigate the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the brain’s processing of it is a central focus of neuroscience. However, the brain’s language system is not a single structure or process, but rather a network of many interacting components. How this network is organized, and how it is related to behavior, is not well understood. We here show that deep learning models, which are known to be good at predicting behavior and neural responses across a range of tasks, also predict brain responses to language in a large group of people. This suggests that the brain’s language system is organized in a way that is predictive of behavior and neural responses, and that this organization may be important for language processing. These results provide a new perspective on the brain’s language system.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. We show that this instability is due to the fact that DL is a special case of a more general problem, which is to compute stable neural networks. We prove that there are problems in scientific computing where stable neural networks exist, but there is no algorithm that can compute them. This result has implications for the development of DL, as well as for scientific computing.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years, and is still a major public health problem in many parts of the world. The causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has been studied for more than a century, and is known to infect the peripheral nerves and the mucosa of the upper respiratory tract. Here, we report the genome sequence of a third tissue reservoir, the skin, which harbors a unique form of leprosy, known as lepromatous leprosy. We also show that the two major species of Mycobacterium that cause leprosy, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, are more closely related to each other than to any other Mycobacterium species. This finding suggests that they have a common ancestor and that they have been evolving together for a very long time. This raises the possibility that they may have a common pathogenic mechanism. Our results have important implications for our understanding of the evolution of the leprosy pathogen and the pathogenesis of the disease. (Show more)

The dynamics of entanglement and entropy in quantum many-body systems is a central topic of current research. In this work, we provide a complete description of the dynamics of entanglement in the space–time scaling limit, which is the appropriate limit to capture the evolution of generic quantum many-body systems. Our result is based on a combination of integrability, quasiparticle picture, and a careful analysis of the steady state. We check our result for the paradigmatic case of the Heisenberg chain, which is a solvable model. Our work provides a framework for the study of the dynamics of entanglement in generic quantum many-body systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of more than 5 million people worldwide. The only vaccine currently in clinical development is based on the SARS-CoV-2 virus, and it is not yet available for widespread use. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate that is based on the same virus, but it is highly attenuated and therefore safer. This vaccine candidate is easy to manufacture, can be stored at room temperature, and is expected to be available for widespread use in the near future.

The Black Death, caused by Yersinia pestis, was one of the deadliest pandemics in human history. The disease spread rapidly through Europe, killing millions of people. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that rats were responsible for the spread of the disease. Here, we present a mathematical model of the spread of plague by a human ectoparasite vector. We show that this model fits the mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death. This has important implications for our understanding of the epidemiology of the disease and the spread of the disease in Europe.

The evolution of brain size has been a central topic in the field of comparative neurobiology. However, to understand the evolution of brain power, we need to know not only the size of the brain but also the number of neurons in the brain. This study provides the most comprehensive dataset of its kind, which allows us to reconstruct the evolution of brain size in amniotes. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The role of TRAP1 in cancer has been the subject of intense investigation. However, the function of TRAP1 in normal cells is less clear. Here, we show that TRAP1 is required for the maintenance of mitochondrial function and for the regulation of metabolic pathways in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. These findings suggest that TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in severing actin filaments. However, the mechanism by which it does so is not known. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF binds to filaments more efficiently in regions of high curvature, but that tension has no effect on binding. Surprisingly, we also find that filament segments that are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist, experience a mechanical torque upon ADF binding. We propose that this torque dramatically enhances severing, which is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our results provide a mechanism for how mechanical stress can enhance the activity of ADF, which is important for understanding how cells respond to mechanical stimuli. This mechanism may also be relevant to other processes that involve actin filaments, such as cell motility.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is found in many foods and beverages. This study shows that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation in regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and for the design of interventions to reduce the risk of obesity.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human population. The settlement history of Madagascar is still debated, and we used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island. We find that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution of European and Middle Eastern origin. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. Our results provide a better understanding of the settlement history of Madagascar and the genetic consequences of the human colonization of the island. This is important for the conservation of the unique biodiversity of Madagascar. It also provides a framework for the study of the genetic consequences of human colonization in general.
